newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - May 8.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Philippine newspapers - May 8.

text.p: These are the leading stories in Manila newspapers on Thursday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Three men, including a law graduate, were sentenced to death penalty after being found guilty of conspiracy for the kidnapping of a businessman on March 25, 1996. (MANILA BULLETIN)

- President Fidel Ramos, starting a 10-day visit to the U.S. West Coast, Mexico and Panama, called for the continued presence of the United States in the Asia-Pacific region. (PHILIPPINE DAILY INQUIRER, MANILA STANDARD)

- Senate President Ernesto Maceda revealed a new Malacanang Palace plot to wrest control of the Senate and convene Congress as a constituent assembly to amend the Constitution if a charter-change petition loses in the Supreme Court. (TODAY)
-Four foreign groups have expressed interest in buying into poultry producer Vitarich Corp, chairman Rogelio Sarmiento said. (BUSINESSWORLD)

- A sizeable amount of government funds were reportedly pumped into Philippine stocks on Monday, giving the marke ta short-lived recovery and handing the President some good news before taking off for his 26th foreign trip the following day. (BUSINESS DAILY)
- The national government reported a turnaround in its budget position from a 648-million peso deficit as of march to a surplus of 6.6. billion by the third week of April. (INQUIRER)
